I believe that The Republic Forward’s candidate, acting President Emmanuel Macron, will win the next presidential election in France. From What I have seen the two candidates who have a chance at beating President Emmanuel Macron are National Rally candidate Marine La Pen or Republicans candidate Valérie Pécresse (BBC News, 2022). While La Pen has a good chance at making it to the run-offs, to face against President Macron, I do not believe that she stands a chance at beating him. La Pen is currently facing backlash due to her past ties with Russian President Valdimir Putin and for her anti-NATO sentiments (Dodman, 2022). The Ukraine Crisis has been favorable to President Macron’s polling numbers (Rose, 2022). La Pen also stands to lose some of her supporters to right wing candidate Eric Zemmour (BBC News, 2022). I do not believe that Eric Zemmour has a chance to face off against President Macron, but I do believe that he can take away from La Pen’s voter base. When Valérie Pécresse first launched her campaign, she quickly rose in polls, since she was views as a pro-European moderate candidate and could appeal to some of President’s Macron’s voters (BBC News, 2022). But as time went on, her numbers have fallen and her campaign has stalled (Signy-L'abbaye, 2022). If she finds a way to reenergize her campaign, she stands a chance face off against President Macron.

When evaluating the standings of France's presidential election coming up, it is evident that the La République En Marche! candidate is set to take the forefront of the election. However, there are also some backings from the other parties that leave a little bit of prediction selections for them. The next best candidate based on my research is Valerie Pecresse, which is a part of the Les Républicains party. She is only slightly behind Macron in the first round of voting intentions. Studies have also shown that Eric Zemmour, who is a part of the Reconquête party has increased some of his favorability. However, the Rassemblement National party has more of a backing than Zemmour.  https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/poll-tips-french-conservative-pecresse-face-macron-2022-presidential-run-off-2021-12-18/

After reading the provided articles and looking at the most recent polling data I think the outside view looks as if a La Republique en Marche (Macron) victory is most likely in a run-off over Rassemblement National (Le Pen).  That said, one thing that jumped out at me in the provided background links was just how unpredictable French politics and elections can be.  It seems that prior to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the biggest challenges to Macron’s re-election bid were shaping up to be from potential far-right candidates Marine Le Pen and Eric Zemmour.  Both have historically been complimentary and friendly toward Russia and Putin, while also pushing a France first agenda over strong ties to the EU and NATO.  The Russian invasion of Ukraine and subsequent strengthening of European and NATO alliances is likely to hurt Le Pen and Zemmour given their previous positions, however it remains to be seen how French voters feel about the strengthening of the EU and NATO alliances and where they see France fitting into that.  How Macron is able to navigate this situation is likely to have a major affect on the ultimate outcome the election.  If he is able to ensure France has a central role in European decisions moving forward I think it will help him, however his failure in gaining much traction in brokering a diplomatic solution prior to the invasion could hurt him a bit as well.  If it appears France is pushed into a backseat, this could sour French voters who may lean toward a more France first agenda.  Either way, a concerning trend is that turnout for the most recent regional elections was down significantly with 66% of registered voters abstaining in the June 2021 elections.  My initial feeling based on my research prior to the formal registration of candidates is that the La Republique en Marche candidate will win the next presidential election in France.  Update: With Macron formally announcing his candidacy and his approval ratings on the rise due largely to his handling of the war in Ukraine thus far, I still believe he is the most likely winner.  Nearly all polling shows him with a comfortable lead as does the election modeling from The Economist referenced below.  The current focus on external affairs is likely to help Macron as other candidates would prefer to focus the discussion on internal issues.  One additional thing to note, with so much volatility in Europe right now, I feel this improves the chances of an unlikely or unexpected event potentially having a significant effect on the election.  Additionally, candidates in the mix with highly polarizing views could lead to surprises as sometimes support might not be fully reflected in polls or models where historical data is used.     Resources: https://www.politico.eu/article/ukraine-invasion-disrupts-french-presidential-campaign/ https://www.politico.eu/article/where-is-france-anti-kremlin-russia-candidate-marine-le-pen-charles-de-gaulle-valerie-pecresse/ https://www.politico.eu/article/macron-expected-to-announce-re-election-bid-friday/ https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20220304-macron-sees-ukraine-war-boost-in-polls-as-he-throws-his-hat-in-the-ring https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022

President Macron will win the next presidential election in France, therefor the La République En Marche! Party will win. My prediction is based primarily from approval ratings and polling data. Round One and Round Two polling as of March 2nd shows Macron with 26% of voter confidence. The next competing candidate trails by a wide margin at 18% (Le Pen). In 2017, Macron beat Le Pen in Round Two polling by a 66% to 34% margin. In order to determine if Le Pen would fare any better in 2022, I evaluated the results of the 2021 regional elections. Le Pen suffered a sharp decline in these elections, with polled voting intentions for her candidacy dropping from 26% to 17%.  Very recent events cannot be discounted for influencing Macron’s chances of re-election. The Russian invasion of Ukraine has united NATO and EU countries together in a unified response, arguably not witnessed since the fall of the USSR. President Macron’s popularity has increased, per polling conducted in France on 25 February, for his handling of the Ukraine crisis. His proactive and assertive attempts at diplomacy with Vladimir Putin in efforts to prevent the invasion, and public support with Ukraine and NATO/EU allies after the invasion, resulted in a five percent increase overnight in public polls by the BVA group. Therefore, Macron’s already strong position in the polls combined with his handling of the Ukraine crisis will secure him re-election in 2022. Sources https://o.nsd.no/european_election_database/country/france/parties.html
https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220304-support-for-macron-shown-rising-amid-ukraine-war-crisis
https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022

Emanual Macron is the current president of France representing the La Republique En Marche (LREM) party and faces re-election on April 10, 2022. According to politico.eu Macron is winning all polls against his constituents. He has a similar or better performance as when he was running in 2017. In 2022, in the first and second round of polls Macron lead 25% and 56% percent. His next closes competition is Le Pen of the political party National Rally who is the run at 17% and 44%. Macron previously worked as economy minister for the previous French president. According to The Economist, Macron is likely to be re-elected as Frace’s president. He does face difficult opposition according to the article no French president has been re-elected in the past 20 years. According to models suggested by the Economist, the next candidate to give him competition is center-right Republican, Valerie Pecresse, with an odds of one in eight chance of being elected. Next in line is Le Pen at one in seventeen. Emmanual Macron is likely to win re-election and continues performing successfully.

The track record of French pollsters is better than their American counterparts. Their sample size is 1,500 (usually) for an adult population of ~51 million, as compared to the American sample size of 1,000 for an adult population of ~258 million. They also have processes to bypass the standards problems of low response rates and getting people to honestly select politically incorrect preferences. Also, French turnout is in the 75%-85% range, which means that polls tend to reflect electoral outcomes. French polls for both rounds in the last 3 elections have proven to be quite predictive. The run-off margin looks set to to be narrower than in 2017, but this election is almost certainly Macron's [to lose].

No French president has been re-elected for 20 years. This April, five years after Emmanuel Macron seized the presidency in his first attempt at winning elected office, voters will decide whether to keep him on for a second term. The Economist’s election model, launched on February 2nd, suggests that they will. It puts Mr Macron’s chance of re-election at 79%. If he wins, the 44-year-old will break yet another rule of French politics. He has a lot of support and has spent the last five years highlighting the issues with NATO which have become everpresent in the Ukraine crisis.

After reading the provided information on France’s state of election, there are several key issues one must look at in order answer the question. First, the French election process is a two-stage process wherein the initial election is will be held on April 10th and the second on April 24th of this year (france24.com). Keeping this in mind and looking at a February 25th, 2022 polling, Macron would receive 24% of the votes in the initial round of twelve candidates. This means 76% of the voting community would vote against Macron. The closest candidate would receive 17%. In addition, polling shows Macron has a 58% disapproval rating (politico.eu) Taking these facts into consideration, if forecast LePen will be the next President of France. https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20210713-france-to-hold-2022-presidential-election-rounds-on-april-10-and-24
https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/

There are two parties I believe that have any chance of winning the next presidential election within France. The frontrunner I believe to be the LaREM party as they are incumbent and most of all organizationally healthy compared to many of the opposition parties that are very fluid in representatives and political organizational capabilities to facilitate large scale political success. The LaREM party has shown that their candidate has the ability to make the final round of voting and will have the financing capable of supporting such a political run. Current polling shows a lead of the LaREM party by varying degrees based on the poll taker. My secondary choice for a victory with about a 20% chance would be the National Rally party as they have a have chosen Marine Le Pen to be their candidate. The current leader of the party she is also the the daughter of the party founder and has with a strong conservative approach to her political opinion may provide an alternative choice to the more moderate LaREM party. This along with an updated overhaul of the values in which the party supports can provide voters with optimism the party is headed in the correct direction and in line with voter opinion. “The leader of the National Rally wants to end immigration, slash crime, eradicate Islamism and save France from globalization, but has rowed back on plans to pull it out of the EU. Her “economic nationalism” would favour French business, while “France-first” social policies in housing, health, education and employment would favour French people. There are signs that her drive to sanitise the party founded by her father, Jean-Marie, in 1972 has cost her some of its traditional support.” The remaining parties seem to have limited ability to mobilize beyond the 20-30% voting rates required to proceed far within the presidential elections. This will result in most likely a showdown between LaREM and a philosophically different party or a battle of conservative values of LaREM against National Rally.   Guardian News and Media. (2022, February 14). French elections 2022: What could happen when country heads to polls? The Guardian. Retrieved February 20, 2022, from https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/14/french-election-2022-polls-macron-le-pen-pecresse

It is almost certain  that Macron (La République en Marche) will be on the ballot for the second round of voting. Both the left (La France Insoumise, Parti socialiste, etc.) and the far right (Rassemblement National, Zemmour) are disorganized and have little chance to make it to the second place in the first round of voting. The Greens are a wild card : they have no chance in the first round, but their supporters may well find Macro unpalatable and vote for the Republicans, if these manage to get in second position in the first round.

Valerie Pecresse is very similar to Macron, but doesn’t have the image that Macron has obtained over the past few years. Macron retains the incumbent benefit and the advertising he’ll get as EU president in the run up to the election, but that is also a risk because anything that goes wrong at the EU level will impact Macron.  This makes Pecresse a “safe” alternative vote for Macron supporters.  This will split the Macron vote in the first round I think Le Pen and Zammour will do well in the first round, but I feel share the same kind of base of support, so even if more votes go to them in total they are likely to split that vote making it harder for either of them.   1st round vote shares are going to be low and quite close because of the above, so we can’t rule out a totally random result on who gets to the second round, which has a huge impact on the probabilities for this forecast.

This is probably the contest he least desires, as Percasse will be able to appeal to a wider portion of the electorate to either Le Pen or Zenmour. But should either of those two reach the run-off against Macron, assuming he makes it there, then he should comfortably be reelected.

Macron beats Le Pen or Zemmour in a run-off almost certainly. Therefore, relevant odds are the chance that Pecresse makes it to the run-off and then the chance that she beats Macron. Macron probably beats Pecresse in run-off but close so 60:40. Pecresse has a good chance of making the run off as she is currently in 2nd but a consolidation of support on the right towards Le Pen or Zemmour could undermine her, therefore 60:40 in her favour. This leaves Pecresse at 3/5*2/5 which is roughly 25%. 15% chance for Zemmour or Le Pen of making the run off and then they probably lose. Valerie Pécresse's victory at the LR internal elections is not convincing. She was doing 10-11% in the polls and could theoretically grow a few percentage points, but not much. She will have to convince a lot of people in her own party and those probably voting Le Pen or Zemmour. Trying to eat into Macron's clientele is even more difficult, although she could poach a few business owners from him looking for a fiscally conservative candidate. But that's not a big enough group to impress electorally.  So I give Le Pen a better chance than Pécresse - for the moment. Let's see how things develop...

This far away a lot can still happen. 
I am particularly expecting some upward movement by the candidate for LR, maneuvering him/herself in a good position between Macron and Le Pen. Le Pen or any other far right candidate will never win as everyone else will rally for the other candidate left or right. On top of that Le Pen will lose half her potential to Zemmour, who has now announced his candidacy. So my bet is at this point: Macron still ahead, Le Pen (or Zemmour for that matter) getting lots of attention but going nowhere, with all eyes on the LR candidate. The latter can get far if the right person will be elected and if he/she plays his/her cards right. For instance a Barnier talking tough on migration and EU may cut into moderate Le Pen voters and so on. Let's see!

Small update to my previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1346626). Zemmour has now officially launched his campaign. It's too early to tell how well this has come across but he obviously got some attention out of it. Youtube has made it necessary to verify your age to see his video, which I expect he will be able to use to his advantage since the video itself pre-empted attempts to "silence" him or his supporters. Zemmour has also been bundled with some personal issues (https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/married-far-right-firebrand-eric-zemmour-gets-chief-aide-pregnant-0b75v6mjr) and fairly unsuccessful events abroad (e.g., London which has many French voters https://www.politico.eu/article/france-eric-zemmour-gets-muted-welcome-in-london-campaign/).
LR have ditched Bertrand as candidate for more right wing candidates, which I am interpreting as either (i) more support for (far-)right politics within LR than previously assumed or (ii) a reaction to Zemmour and trying to position themselves in a way that avoids leaking too many votes to Zemmour. (Likely, it is a combination of both.) This supports the idea that if Zemmour makes the second round he could take many of the first round LR votes with him to the second round. With the two possible LR candidates being unexpected to the extent that is little polling that includes them, it's too early to really tell whether they actually have a better chance of reaching the second round (or winning) than Bertrand, but there is no evidence to suggest this at the moment. Rather, it seems like the Zemmour/RN/LR vote will be further split and, in my opinion, more likely to be taken by the more extreme candidate for those further right, which is Zemmour, and Macron for the more moderate right wing voters.
Macron is still to officially announce his candidacy but is stable in polls despite Zemmour now being a clear candidate, suggesting that his base is solid. Seeing the impact of the results over in LR will be interesting to determine whether LR voters aligned with Bertrand will shift to Macron or remain LR voters and, by extension, possible second round Zemmour voters. As a result, I've given a higher score to LREM, which for now seems to have been unaffected by Zemmour's campaign launch, and a slightly lower score to Zemmour whose campaign has not been able to capitalise on his rise in the polls and make him the established second round candidate.

latest Harris survey here: https://harris-interactive.fr/opinion_polls/barometre-dintentions-de-vote-pour-lelection-presidentielle-de-2022-vague-21/ Most relevant slides are 8 (first round, assuming Xavier Bertrand becomes the Republican nominee) and 21 (Macron's head-to-heads against the 5 major candidates). Notably Macron wins in all the hypothetical head-to-heads with 55% or greater, and has shown improvement in his matchups against Zemmour and Bertrand. Further breakdowns are interesting, where survey-takers are asked how they will vote in various scenarios if their 1st round candidate does not advance. Perhaps the most promising news for Macron is that Bertrand's first-round voters are more likely to favor him to Zemmour, 48-21%. The same voters prefer Macron to Le Pen, 47-19%. This suggests the two "extreme right" candidates will not be able to consolidate the more mainstream right-wing voters, who prefer the bland technocratic approach of Macron. Likewise, if Bertrand advances, a majority of both Zemmour and Le Pen voters announce their intentions to abstain in the second round. In short, even though there are more voters to Macron's right than his left, they are just as fractious and unwilling to accept (at this early stage) alternate standard-bearers. While I still expect this race to tighten, this is largely good news for Macron; he is un-loved but also not hated, about the best a national politician can hope for in contemporary France.
Very hard to see a situation where Macron doesn’t win.

https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/new-poll-puts-zemmour-round-two-french-vote-behind-president-macron-2021-10-22/ One of the very stupidest things about using the image of a race to discuss a political outcome is that it inspires the press and others to get giddy (since they think a race, they express this in giddy yaps) at every poll that comes out, whenever it comes out and however close it is.  This election is not scheduled until Spring, and Zemmour isn't even an announced candidate.  If this mattered, Newt Gingrich would have completed two terms as Prez of the US. Full disclosure:  I inveighed against this nonsense in much the same terms in the 2016 US elections.   And we know how that turned out.

Because neither Macron (currently president, leading the polls) nor Zemmour (outsider, rapidly climbing the polls) have yet to officially launch their campaign, it is still early to make confident predictions. I am basing my prediction based on the following points. (i) Le Pen (RN candidate) does not have a chance of winning as far as I can tell. With respect to the first round, she is polling much lower than in 2017 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Graphical_summary), where she relied primarily on past Le Pen voters and to a smaller extent on other right wing voters and neither left nor right voters. There are many right wing alternatives to her in the upcoming election, which will split her voter base.  Even if she reached the second round, she still polls unfavourably against Macron (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Macron_vs._Le_Pen) and has already lost to him once. (ii) Macron (LREM candidate) is the current president. French presidents do not normally win a second term (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_France#Presidents_2). In what may turn out to be history rhyming, the last one to do so (Chirac, 2002) did so against Le Pen's father because of how despised Le Pen's father was. Macron is not polling particularly well, neither in the presidential polls nor in his approval ratings as president (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_on_the_Emmanuel_Macron_presidency#Graphical_summary), although they have improved recently. Macron could market himself as a choice for stability following the (ongoing) covid-19 crisis and the opportunity to announce radical policies. His opponents are also fairly divided and splitting the everything-but-macron vote between each other. On the other hand, he could also face a resurgence of the gillet jaunes movement if his government fails to address new and pre-existing problems. The fact that Macron has not yet officially announced his intention to seek re-election means that he may be waiting for more positive polls or some announcement that he expects to move pools in his favour. (I do not have data on how early or late outgoing french presidents officially announce they are seeking re-election.) (iii) Bertrand (LR) could look like an alternative choice to Le Pen for traditional, small c, right wing voters, but Macron has himself movedto the right(as opposed to his more centrist position in 2017) and is currently more popular. The crowd seems to give Bertrand a chance, but to me there is no evidence that he has it in him to run a successful enough campaign to make up his current deficit. The only circumstances that could be favourable to him would be if Macron decided not to seek re-election. He has been polling well against Macron himself in a second round scenario (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election#Macron_vs._Bertrand) so it seems plausible that he would be able to rack up some Macron votes if Macron were not around. (iv) Melenchon has not managed to rally a popular left wing movement and is polling even worse than in 2017. He did have a late surge in the polls in 2017, but it was not enough to make it to the second round and I don't believe it would be enough to make it to the second round this time either. Should he reach the second round he would lose with a very high probability as he does not have a broad support base and could face every other candidate aligning against him, or at the very least not supporting him. (v) France is quite socially conservative and uncomfortable with issues of race, religion, and sexism. There are no social justice oriented candidates with broad support, and even Macron has increasingly leaned into right wing narratives on these issues rather than towards more progressive views. (v) Zemmour's recent surge in the polls, despite not being an official candidate, suggests that there is a real voter base for an "right wing outsider, anti-establishment candidate that tells it like it is". Being a well known journalist, author and media personality that is accustomed to live TV debates, Zemmour has the potential to run a successful media campaign. 
Macron in 2017 benefitted from marketing himself as a modern outsider to the political establishment and proposing a change from the french political establishment. In the end, Macron has maybe suffered from turning out to be too much like the establishment that people wanted to get rid of. Zemmour is even more of an outsider, with more extreme views in many regards (particularly on racism, islam, feminism, and LGBT+ issues) that will fetch the far right vote, but he also seems to be able to capture some of the broader dissatisfied-with-the-system vote that he has been able to reach through his media work and existing notoriety. His views are not necessarily unpopular with french voters.
If Zemmour succeeds in taking over more of Le Pen's voters along with some other right wing voters that do not like Macron and Melenchon voters, he would be in a good position to reach the second round. If that happens, it seems that Zemmour will face the same hostility that Le Pen's father did in 2002 (which allowed Chirac to win despite his unpopularity) because he already is well established and accepted. Considering Macron's unpopularity, this leaves the door open for a second round Zemmour win in my opinion.
Macron wins over Eric Zemmour, who makes it through but who's policies are seen as unpalatable by the majority.
Hasn't been an incumbent winning for 20 years; However, 'fringe' candidates, such as far right,l are weeded out in 2nd round

Couple of points to consider: - Since Jacques Chirac in 2002, no president was re-elected in France.  - On September 16, Zemmour - a far-right journalist- published La France n’a pas dit son dernier mot (France hasn’t had its last word), which topped the bestseller list on Amazon France, selling about 130,000 copies in the two weeks after release.
- Mondon - a politics professor who researches racism and the far right- described Le Pen’s election poster as a “desperate attempt to pretend that she’s addressing the mainstream”. - Jean-Luc Mélenchon, La France Insoumise leader, impressed in 2017 with nearly 20 percent – the highest for a left-wing candidate.
But, as he gears up for his third presidential campaign, he is seen as an ageing figure and has shed core supporters. - "According to some media reports, many who voted for Macron in the second round in 2017 would not vote for him again next year, even if he faces a far-right candidate."

The Republicans are an old established party that appears to be weakening but they could be a fallback if Macron and the far right are unpalatable.

Party politics in France appear to be in weakening in the country. Macron won the presidency without an established party, but his La République En Marche! Has also dematerialised having no power in any single region. However, Macron would appear to be the front runner given the weakness of the opposition, rather than his strength.
The Socialists are polling no better than 2017 where they scored 6% of the vote, the Greens are struggling and a grouping of others further to the left showing no inclination to give way to any other.
The centre right has probably suffered from the demise of the traditional political parties in France.
There has been a surge from the far right from a TV political commentator and journalist, Eric Zammour who has confirmed the further weakening of political parties but could split the far-right vote with Le Pen and thereby aiding Macron in the process.
I am showing Eric Zammour as 'none of the above' and 0% for the traditional parties, left and centre.

There's a long list of declared candidates [1][2], and a long list of parties [3].  Some possible names are: Marine Le Pen (National Rally or RN) (far right)
Emmanuel Macron (The Republic Forward or LREM) (center)
Xavier Bertrand (Les Républicains or LR) [4] (right)
Michel Barnier (Les Républicains or LR) (right)
Jean-Luc Mélenchon (Unbowed France or FI or LFI) (left) Eric Zemmour has not declared, and is a right-wing anti-immigration journalist with positions similar to Le Pen.
Les Républicains will nominate their candidate on December 4. [5]
Anne Hidalgo (Socialist Party or PS) won the Socialists' presidential nomination on October 14th [6].

It's too early to learn much from the polls, with better predictions expected in February. [7]  Both Macron's party and Le Pen's party did poorly in the June election, with low turnout. Percentage of votes received were: Les Républicains 29%, National Rally 19%, Socialist party 17%, La République En Marche (LREM) 11% of votes [8].  Based on this result, Les Républicains has a solid base of voters to work with.  I expect Macron to fade in the polls in the next few months, with those center voters spliting between Les Républicains and the Socialists. Les Républicains would then face either National Rally or the Socialists in the second round. I would expect LR to beat NR, and LR to be about twice as likely to win as PS. My initial probability calculation is: LR 50% first round * 100% second round + 50%*70% = 85%
NR 50% first round * 0% second round = 0%
PS 50% first round * 30% second round = 15% This forecast (0,0,85,0,15) is quite different than the crowd (19,56,25,0,0). I will adjust my numbers somewhat towards the crowd: 5% Le Pen, National Rally (Rassemblement National)
25% Macron,  The Republic Forward (La République En Marche!)
55%, Bertrand, The Republicans (Les Républicains)
0%, Mélenchon, Unbowed France (La France Insoumise)

This is going to be an interesting election.  I need to do a bit more reading.  But based on what I know now, feelings about Macron are all over, but the opposition is more split than it was in the past even. Considering the amount of right wing politics in Europe we can’t discount the right wing and I’d have to see if anyone is more organised and funded than RN, but Zemmour, while not yet declared, maybe making people think that the far right of French politics may not need the Le Pen name. And if Le Pen is trying to attract slightly less far right wing votes, that may lose her a bunch that remain far right.  Tricky game she’s playing. Given the unpredictability of recent years anything could end up happening, after Macron himself came a bit out of nowhere (not that he wasn’t already establishment though), so can’t say 0 on any line right now. But I struggle to see beyond Macron winning at the moment.  With COVID and all kinds of other things, better the devil you know might be the feeling. I’m also quite interested as well in the number of the the first time politicians in En Marche that were elected last time that will stand again.  They may not be interested.  But if they do stay will it really establish En March more permanently?
